title: Expression of Interest - Professional Facilities Management Service Provider - 1 William Street, Brisbane
description: The Queensland Government Accommodation Office, through QBuild is seeking expressions of interest (EOI) for Comprehensive Professional Facilities Management Services for the 1 William Street Building, Brisbane Qld.Suitably experienced Facilities Management Providers are invited to download the Invitation Documentation and thoroughly review the mandatory requirements of the EOI.1 William Street transforms and revitalizes the parliamentary end of George and William Streets, Brisbane. The development of the 1 William Street commercial office tower has been the catalyst for the entire George Street government precinct to be redeveloped.The office tower, which is the home of the Queensland Government and public service, comprises a 43 level, A-Grade commercial office building with Premium services, providing approximately 75,000m2 (NLA), including 1,000m2 of retail space - the latter of which is leased to the private sector.  The 4 basement levels provide 316 car parks, loading areas, extensive “end of trip” facilities for approximately 600 bicycles and storage with associated plant and back of house services.Floor plates range from approximately 1,900m2 to 2,100m2.1 William Street includes a high level of environmental credentials, targeting a minimum 5.0 Star Green Star Office Design Rating (V3) and a 5.0 Star NABERS (National Australian Built Environment Rating System) Energy Rating.This Expression of Interest (EOI) process will result in a shortlist of suitably assessed, Facilities Management Service Providers. The EOI contains 100% weighting for Non-Price Criteria, with mandatory criteria which are required to be met for a Tenderer to be considered for evaluation or shortlisting.The successfully shortlisted suppliers will then be invited to provide a fee proposal based on their EOI submission and additional non-price criteria responses.  The weighting applied will be 70% Price & 30% Non-Price.All Requests for Information pertaining to the Expression of Interest are to be directed to QBuildStrategicSourcing@hpw.qld.gov.au

title: Mooloolaba State School - New Learning Centre (Eligible PQC Contractors Level 3)
description: The Department of Education (DoE) is calling for submissions for the construction of a new 2 storey Learning Centre located at Mooloolaba State School, 15 Meta St, Mooloolaba QLD 4557.Tender submissions will be accepted from contractors satisfying PQC 3 level certification with QA and a registered office at the Sunshine Coast. Please note, the contract will be awarded as a whole to a suitably licenced contractor. Individual trade packages will not be awarded separately.Tender documentation is available for collection from Lambert Rehbein (SEQ).  Please email your interest in this project along with your company PQC certificate to Robert Gordon Robert.g@lar.net.au.Please contact Robert Gordon (Senior Project Manager) on telephone 07 3250 9000 or Robert.g@lar.net.au for further information.Submissions close on Wednesday, 24 March 2021 at 2:00pm at the Queensland Government Tender Box, C/o Decipha Pty Ltd, 2 Duncan Street, West End QLD 4101.

title: Renewable Energy Projects EOI
description: Stanwell Corporation is a major provider of electricity to Queensland, the National Electricity Market and large commercial and industrial energy users throughout Australia. While providing reliable and affordable energy for today, Stanwell is also exploring innovative generation and storage options that will help reduce emissions for tomorrow.We are looking to partner with commercial renewable energy projects based in Queensland to help us meet customer demand for green energy and support Queensland's transition to a lower carbon future.Project Proponents are invited to express their interest within the following categories:- Mature projects - Power Purchase Agreements (PPA) and equity investment opportunities for well advanced projects.- Early Stage projects - investment opportunities for less advanced projects which can form a part of Stanwell's future portfolio.For further information please refer to Section 3 for the EOI documents.

title: Security Guarding Services
description: This scope of work provides for security services for Powerlink Queensland’s Virginia Complex situated at 33 Harold Street and 36 Northlink Place, Virginia.  The complex comprises four (4) buildings and is surrounded by landscaped gardens and car parks;	The Edison building a two (2) level building with approximately 6,000 square metres of office accommodation and amenities and approximately 600 square metres of landscaped court.	The Tesla Building being a single level with mezzanine building with approximately 14,000 square metres of workshop, laboratories and office accommodation.	The Brian Sharp building being a four (4) level building with approximately 4,200 square metres of office accommodation.	36 Northlink Place being a two (2) level building with approximately 8,000 square metres of  warehouse, production and office accommodation; which is linked to the Virginia complex via a pedestrian gate.

The PPE is worn by staff working in a variety of environments including construction sites, maintenance and plant operations, outdoor operations and by drivers of heavy fleet and plant vehicles. PPE range should be easily ordered and promptly supplied to staff throughout Queensland.The required PPE product categories include:	glasses / accessories	gloves	hearing / head equipment	respiratory equipment	other (e.g. backpack with reflective tape, knee pad, high visibility polar fleecy beanie)Important note: Queensland Rail currently uses a web-based integrated solution for the procurement of PPE. To be considered for this tender you MUST have the ability to integrate with Queensland Rail using Open Catalogue Interface. PROCESS OVERVIEWAriba Sourcing, Queensland Rail’s tendering system, is the only tendering tool that Tenderers must use to submit their responses. title: GE00462 WATER MAIN UPGRADE - COMMERCIAL FISHING BASE 2
description: Commercial Fishing Base No.2 (CFB2) is located on Chinaman Creek near the Maritime Safety Queensland base. Road access is via CFB2 Access Road off Tingira Street, Portsmith, Cairns, QLD.The wharf forming CFB2 was constructed in the late 1980’s and primarily consists of a steel substructure with a pre cast concrete deck. The original water main was constructed from 100mm galvanised steel and protected with densowrapping. The reticulation forms a ring main, approximately 300lm, around the outer edge of the concrete deck. Painted steel brackets attached by bolts through the deck are utilised to fix the pipe work to the wharf. The position of this water main renders it vulnerable to impact damage from fishing vessels and over time there have been many sections of pipe and brackets physically deformed. Significant water main failures commenced from 2012 when the asset was around 25 years old. Over a 4 year period approximately 100m of the galvanised pipe was replaced but not protected with denso wrap and some sections are already showing signs of significant surface corrosion. Of the remaining 200m approximately 50m is damaged. The remainder is difficult to assess by visual inspection only but the denso wrapping is damaged so not providing a reliable corrosion barrier and there are spots with isolated leaks. Given the age of the original galvanised main is reaching 35 years, within a corrosive marine environment, the risk of continual leaks caused by pitting in the near future is high. Since 2012 this water asset has cost the Port $40K to maintain. Therefore, more sustainable water supply options will be considered for the future of CFB2. A fire system is not required on CFB2 so nonmetallic options such as polyethylene can be utilised. Ports North are open to consider any sustainable options with whole of life cost benefits. The benefits of installing a polyethylene water main suspended centrally under the deck next to the electrical cable ladder include; Halving the linear distance of the main line Eliminating the risk of vessel impact damage Clearing services away from the steel girders which will significantly reduce future blast and paint maintenance costs Eliminate corrosive metallic materials Increase asset life and reduced whole of life costs Simple to repair in the event of damage Lower cost than maintaining and upgrading the existing reticulation with denso wrapped galvanised steel

title: SOA  Preferred Supplier Panel for the provision of supply and delivery of Construction Materials for RoadTek
description: The Queensland Government is seeking Proposals for the establishment of a Standing Offer Arrangement, Preferred Supplier Panel (PSP) for the provision of supply and delivery of construction materials for RoadTek in the Technical categoryies of Bridges and other Structures; Geotechnical; Intelligent Transport Systems & Electrical; and Traffic Engineering and Road Safety.This Invitation to Offer aims to appoint Suppliers who hold current TMR registered supplier status and have an approved product(s); or are a supplier of a conforming and/or a suitable product; or has batch approval.Currently there are seven (7) Standing Offer Arrangements (SOA) due to expire in 2021.  These Arrangements were established for RoadTek's use and are for various products which form part of the core of TMR’s mandate to deliver and maintain a reliable transport network across the state.  To improve efficiencies for both suppliers and the department, RoadTek would like to establish a new arrangement to encompass the majority of the required construction material products for RoadTek's use.  Having an Arrangement in place, allows RoadTek to procure these products under agreed term and conditions and on an "as and when/where required" basis; however, there is no guarantee on the volume of purchases.RoadTek is interested in a supply distribution network to cover products identified under this arrangement.  Distribution within regions would be considered favourably as this potentially decreases lead times and freight costs to our organisation.  RoadTek would work with successful Offerors and the supply chain to ensure mutual benefits are achieved.  There are nine (9) RoadTek regional areas (Cairns; North Queensland; Mackay; Central Queensland; Wide Bay / Burnett; Downs South West; Sunshine Coast; Brisbane and Gold Coast Regions).Exclusions:	Installation of products	Some products under the technical category for Pavements, Materials and Geotechnical are excluded, products associated with this category can be found at Pavements, materials and geotechnical (Department of Transport and Main Roads) (tmr.qld.gov.au).	Asphalt, Bitumen, Quarries, Spray seals – Aggregate precoating agents and ready-mix concrete. Registered Suppliers under Construction Materials Testing (CMT) – Laboratory Registration is excluded and is covered under SOA TMR14716. Also excluded in this Invitation to Offer is the Registered Prequalified Asphalt Contractors.For further details on exclusions, refer to Section 3.4 of the Invitation to Offer document.For detailed information on the specific goods / services sought under this tender, please review the "Specification Documents" in "Section 3 - Here is the detail".

title: Invitation To Submit Tender - G26 Main Switchboard Replacement, (within G29 Chiller House), Gold Coast campus
description: Dear TenderersYou are invited to submit a Tender to carry out all works associated with the G26 Main Switchboard Replacement  at the Gold Coast campus, Griffith University.The G26 Building contains vital science laboratories.Maintaining services and operations to the building is critical.To reduce operational risk a new diesel generator is proposed to be located in adjacent building G29 to provideemergency power. The scope of this project is to complete building works and associated services upgrades required to accommodate the new generator.Building modifications to building G29, including removal of walls, installation of louvres for air flow and the construction of a small building to house the new G26 Switchboard are part of scope. Design, delivery, installation and commissioning of the new G26 switchboard and all associated electrical work is also within scope.The generator is to be provided by others and the supply and delivery of it is not part of this contract. Liaison with the generator supplier is required during the course of the works. It is anticipated the generator will be craned to site in mid May 2021.As part of the annual certification requirements for critical laboratories in building G26, an annual shutdown is undertaken for maintenance.For 2021 the shutdown works are scheduled to commence on 1st June 2021 until11 June 2021.Works to test and commission the switchboard will need to be finalised prior to a full load generator test on Friday 11 June 2021.Tenders close at 1:00pm on Wednesday, 10 March 2021 3 March 2021 via the QTenders link associated with this project in accordance with the Conditions of Tender.  A Tender submitted late or by any other means than that nominated may not be accepted.Mandatory site inspections with tenderers will take place on Friday 19 February 2021, by appointment only. Request for site access for inspection should be directed to the PD&C Project Manager, Michael Terry on mobile 0466 866 327 or email Michael.terry@griffith.edu.au. This fully funded project is being tendered on the open market, to be awarded so that works can be completed by the required date.Please note that Tenders will not be opened publicly. All details are provided herein.Thank you.

title: Digital Assessment Tool for Schools
description: BackgroundThe Department of Education and Training (the Department) are seeking to provide access to third-party assessment tools currently used by schools at a discount when compared to the advertised retail rate they currently receive.The tools support schools to assess student learning outcomes and needs.Providing Schools with access to  quality assessment tool instruments will support a Departmental narrative into 2021 that schools should identify quality-assured assessment tools that they will use as part of their planned approach to student assessment,these aim to inform which teaching strategies should be used for greatest impact upon learning at the local level.

title: MELBOURNE WHOLESALE FLOWER MARKET RESEARCH PROJECT
description: For Melbourne Wholesale Flower Market Research, Ref No: MMA26/02/21Melbourne Market Authority (MMA) invites you to submit a Quotation for the delivery of Services described in Part B of this Request for Quotation (RFQ), in accordance with the Quotation Conditions in Part A.									To													Organisation Name									 													Contact Name									 													Email									 													Phone									 													Mobile									 						 									Details Schedule													RFQ Contact Person 									David Power													Email									david.power@melbournemarket.com.au													Phone									03 9258 6105													RFQ Issue Date									04 March 2021													Closing Time 									2:00 pm Local Time in Melbourne, Australia			Friday 09 April 2021													Lodgement Method									Alternative 1			Electronic Lodgement by email: 			Through the Vic Tenders website 			Please quote the RFQ Reference Number and Title in the subject line of the email.													Evaluation Criteria									MMA will assess quotations against the following evaluation criteria and then compare them to determine which offers best overall value for money taking account of whole of life costs including risks to MMA:							proposed solution				capability				capacity				commercial				price																Site tour									A site tour is available at 6:00am to 9:00am Thursday 18 March 2021. RSVP for the tour no later than 2:00pm, Tuesday 16 March 2021 via email to: david.power@melbournemarket.com.au													Question Protocols and Last Date for Questions									Questions or requests for clarification should be submitted in writing by email to the RFQ Contact Person, no later than 2:00 pm, Monday 5 April 2021.			MMA may elect not to answer questions or requests for clarification received after that time.			All questions and their responses will be issued as an email circular on a periodic basis throughout the RFQ open period.  Questions may be edited including to remove the identity of the enquirer.						   IntroductionOur VisionThe Melbourne Wholesale Flower Market (MWFM) supplies 60% of Australia’s fresh cut flowers. At the Market there are 152 trader stands that are a mix of growers and wholesalers, of whom sell to retailers, florists, event managers, hospitality, weddings, and funeral industries.The MMA’s vision is to provide an unappareled service centre for all businesses to conduct their flower trade business through a deeper understanding about the needs, challenges and opportunities that are available within the market and across Victoria.Our mission in this strategic planTo develop a vibrant and sustainable market by responding proactively to the fundamental shifts in the flower trading environment whilst helping our clients to adapt.Our commitmentWe approach our work and each other with a commitment to:	Act with honesty, integrity and respect for others;	Engage openly with all our stakeholders;	Assist the development of our market community and their businesses; and	Support the growth of Victoria’s fresh cut flower economy.Our objectives under the MMA Act	Provide a commercially viable wholesale facility for the efficient distribution of fresh cut flowers.	Optimise returns on land assets controlled and managed by the authority.	Ensure a fair and competitive environment for the wholesale trading of produce.Strategic Objectives and deliverables in the 3-year Corporate Plan (2019/20 – 2022/23)									 									Strategic Intent									Outcome													Continuously improve the operating environment									Continually seek and pursue opportunities to improve the cost effectiveness, efficiency and safety of the market site									Cost of operations for the MMA and customers is reduced without impacting user experience			Reportable incidents are reduced													 									 									 													Maximise the utility of the trading floors									Lead opportunities to improve the vibrancy and functionality of the market floors									Increased utilisation of market facilities and services													 									 									 													Drive logistical efficiency									Respond to the increasingly important role that the market plays as a logistics hub									Improved logistical efficiency													 									 									 													Precinct master planning									Identification of services / facilities that could be delivered within the existing market land and the market future development area									Create new revenue streams that increase (1) the financial viability of the MMA and (2) the Market’s value proposition for users													 									 									 													Support export growth									Assist our clients to leverage the growing export opportunity									Increased export volume through market													 									 									 													Embrace digital change									Identify opportunities to improve the customer’s experience, efficiency and transparency of the market with digital technology									Digital strategy and implementation plan for digital transformation													 									 									 						Part A – Quotation ConditionsBy submitting a Quotation in response to this functional and performance requirements identified by the MMA.		The MMA may:	change any details in the RFQ	extend the Closing Time	reject any unacceptable Quotation including your Quotation	negotiate with one or more Respondents	accept the whole or any part of a Quotation (including your Quotation) or more than one Quotation.MMA’s Specific Rights:	the MMA is not bound to accept the lowest or any Quotation, and warrants only that all valid Quotations will receive due and diligent consideration	no correspondence will be entered regarding unsuccessful Quotations. However, the MMA may offer a debriefing to unsuccessful respondents.	whilst generally intending to proceed with the process as outlined, the MMA does not guarantee to proceed and reserves the right to vary the process, appoint other advisors to assist with all or part of the requirement or make no appointment.Part B - SpecificationScopeThe Melbourne Market Authority (MMA) invites you to submit a quotation for a research exercise of the MMA’s flower market.The research will provide a ‘pulse check’ on the current and evolving needs, as well as a cultural assessment of tenants and buyers related to the Melbourne Wholesale Flower Market (MWFM). Furthermore, once this research is gathered, we are seeking recommendations as to the appropriate strategic response.	BackgroundThe Melbourne Wholesale Flower Market (MWFM) supplies 60% of Australia’s fresh cut flowers. At the Market there are 152 trader stands that are a mix of growers and wholesalers, of whom sell to retailers, florists, event managers and hospitality industry.MWFM relocated to a state-of-the-art facility in Epping in 2015. This saw a shift in the flower industry and the role of the MWFM.  Many growers reviewed their sales model and moved to supplying the market and selling through a distributor in the market or opened for farm gate sales. This was one of the many factors that attributed to the current downturn being experienced at the MWFM.  Other factors include:	a shift in flower industry to move to event or online florists rather than retail stores	increasing costs to travel to the market	hours of operation etc.	increased supply of imports (not during COVID, but normally)	culture of the market	supply and range	increasing number of wholesalers on the outskirtsCOVID has provided opportunities for the MWFM’s wholesalers and retailers who have been able to adjust and adopt throughout COVID. Some have done this by targeting lockdown customers through flower deliver or moving to buying and selling online, although overall  the with increasing costs and imports has resulted in the MWFM experiencing an overall downturn. The Melbourne Market Authority has a vested interested in boosting the Victorian Flower Industry, in particular, ensuring the MWFM remains a key component of the Victorian supply chain in whichever form that takes. The primary purpose of this research is to:	pulse check of market users, both stand holders, buyers and past users	gain a clear understanding of customers experience in using the market; and create a plan to make this journey a positive one	pulse check on culture of the market and what effects this has on user experience	map the customer experience for accessing the market (sign up) and traditional buying experience	challenges for sellers in the market 	understand why past users are no longer using the marketThis research can be conducted by (open to recommendations); survey groups of key flower market groups e.g. growers, users, florists, advisory committees, non-users, past users and any other relevant parties.A pulse check on what the MWFM offers, ability to access, its short falls, what can be improved and changes that need to be made to enhance user experience and attendance. A consultant is sought to provide advice, recommendations and possible courses of action to address what would enhance the MWFM and enhance the experience of the cohorts that use it. The work will be completed in a number of phases:Phase 1Discussion with the Melbourne Market Authority team as an initial briefPhase 2Discussion with the Flower Market Advisory CommitteePhase 3A mixed method approach to survey wholesalers, growers and florists. (past users, non-users, education institutes)Phase 4 Identify concerns, issues within the market from key segments. Test reaction to changes.Phase 5Provide a summary report of the research and recommendations 	Project Outcomes / objectivesThe purpose of this research is to do a pulse check on the MWFM and map a plan to increase patronage and loyalty to the MWFM. This research is required to understand the culture (internal /external perspective), sense of place/ownership, challenges, reputation, understand the decline in patronage, market competition and changes required to see MWFM as the market leader.The key objectives of the project are to:	Survey and engage with a cross section of tenants, users, buyers and stakeholders of the Melbourne Wholesale Flower Market.	Survey to grasp an understanding of culture, customer service, complaints procedure, opportunities for improvement, what can be done to improve patronage and economic viability of the Flower Market/maximise its potential.	Outcome dependent, to identify a road map / list of recommendations to achieve the MWFM full potential.1. Performance MeasuresThe following is required to be delivered or carried out as part of this projects:	A 6am tour of the Melbourne Wholesale Flower Market	A briefing meeting with the Melbourne Market Authority staff	In-person, zoom, telephone one-on-one meetings with key stakeholders involved with the Melbourne Wholesale Flower Market (depending on COVID-19 restrictions)	Focus groups, survey, phone interviews with key groups (as outline above)	Discuss findings and do check in with MMA staff	Final report inclusive of research findings and recommendations.	Important DatesThe following are the key milestones for this project and can be negotiated from April to June with the preferred agency: 	Brief the Agency	Quote due	Agency appointment	Agency Briefing from the MMA	Flower Market tour if needed	One-on-one meetings	Focus Group	Final Report	Customer Relationship ManagementThe project will involve a close working relationship with the project lead for the MMA and understanding the Melbourne Market community and prospective tenants for the developable land.	Reporting RequirementsThe Project Lead is David Power, Commercial and Business Development Manager, Melbourne Market Authority.Weekly written (email acceptable) updates outlining progress against milestones with the Project Lead.If issues were to arise it is expected they are identified with the client immediately for consideration and rectification options.Any instances of scope variation are to be flagged and approved prior to action / implementation.Part C - Conditions of Contract Through this RFQ process, the evaluation panel seeks to contract a Service Provider for the provision of the services outlined in Part B. The evaluation panel’s intention is to avoid protracted contractual negotiations.From that starting point, the evaluation panel intends to negotiate contract terms for the provision of the services outlined in Part B with the preferred Tenderer(s). Tenderers are encouraged to provide realistic commercial terms (e.g. in relation to liability caps, insurance, warranties, indemnities, etc.) as Tenderers’ contractual positions will be considered in the evaluation process when determining a preferred tenderer.PRINCIPLES FOR CONTRACTING The evaluation panel’s objectives are that:	Entering into a contract as soon as possible which requires minimum necessary contractual negotiations and a commitment to achieve this through negotiations in good faith.	Contractual terms should not be inconsistent with the evaluation panel’s requirements as outlined in this document or Part B, and should accommodate the following principles:	The proposed contractual arrangements should be facilitative of the Part B Specification – i.e. not amend (without specifically detailing as a departure) any aspects of the Specification; and	The proposed contractual arrangements should cater for the implementation and the business as usual phases of the project.   Part D - Quotation Form for Developable Land – identification and scoping of uses, Ref No: dliasou190628Quotation OfferBy this Quotation, I/we offer to provide the Goods and/or Services described in Part B in accordance with the Contract Conditions in Part C on the basis set out in this Quotation Form.
